DOC.HEAD: Bostonians Re-enact Tea Protest
DOC.TEXT: People dressed as early Colonists and American Indians rushed aboard a ship and dumped boxes of ``tea'' into Boston Harbor on the 216th anniversary of the Boston Tea Party. The re-enactment Sunday evening of the Colonials' protest against British tariffs took on a modern twist as some of the 50 or so spectators, wary of how the Legislature might try to ease Massachusetts' budget problems, shouted, ``No new taxes!'' Under cover of night, with temperatures in the low teens, 15 to 20 people hacked into tea boxes and threw the contents _ leaves instead of tea _ from the brig Beaver II into the harbor, just as Colonials did with 347 boxes in 1773. Nine ``Redcoats'' then boarded the ship, and escorted the ``Colonials'' off to fife and drum music. The Tea Party was a protest of British tariffs on the brew and England's practice of taxing Colonial Americans without allowing them representation in Parliament. The protest helped spark the Revolutionary War less than two years later. ``I'm a loyal revolutionary believing unjust taxes shouldn't be on something we can get for a cheaper price,'' said Joe Kolb of Watertown, who has played a Colonist in the re-enactment since 1976. ``I'll be here as long as I can swing an ax,'' said Kolb, a field investigator for a utility company. ``We whipped the citizens into a frenzy about the tea, and they decided to do something about it,'' said John Vann, speaking as Sam Adams, the ``ringleader'' of the original protest. Vann, chairman of the Massachusetts Council of Minutemen and Militia, wore Colonial garb and a ponytailed wig. He said the tea and debris from the boxes would be removed from the already polluted harbor by a Boston Tea Party Ship and Museum employee in a canoe.
